ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Precipitation in
α
$\alpha$ -Fe based Fe-Cu-Ni-Mn-alloys: behaviour of Ni and Mn modelled by ab initio and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Institut für Materialprüfung, Werkstoffkunde und Festigkeitslehre (IMWF)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
A kinetic Monte Carlo approach is used to study the behaviour of Ni and Mn solutes in
α
$\alpha$ -Fe containing Cu, Ni and Mn foreign atoms. The simulation method is based on a vacancy diffusion model. Regarding precipitation, the crucial parameters of this method are the mixing energies of all contained elements. These are determined using ab initio calculations taking into account temperature by varying the lattice constant. It is found that the behaviour of Ni and Mn solutes which can form NiMn-precipitates, NiMn-shells around Cu precipitates or stay in solution changes significantly with small changes in the mixing energies.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Motivated by the observed ductility reduction of some reactor pressure vessel steels and weldments in pipelines, the contribution of alloying elements in
α
$\alpha$ -Fe has been investigated extensively by experiments as well as simulations. It is well known that clusters enriched in Cu, Ni and Mn which form during thermal aging or irradiation are crucial regarding embrittlement. Experimental techniques as small angle neutron scattering, field emission scanning transmission electron microscopy and atom probe tomography were used to study the composition and structure of these clusters [1–9]. There is agreement about the presence of Cu-rich precipitates in thermally aged or irradiated
α
$\alpha$ -Fe. Regarding Ni and Mn, the observed structures are more versatile. Depending on concentrations and conditions during thermal or irradiation treatment, Mn and Ni were found in MnNi-rich precipitates [7], in B2 ordered Ni(Al, Mn) domains [8], accumulated in shells around Cu-rich precipitates [1, 8], in Cu-rich precipitates [2, 7] or dissolved in the matrix [9]. Modelling of precipitation in
α
$\alpha$ -Fe has been carried out using kinetic Monte Carlo simulations with a vacancy diffusion based mechanism. It was shown that this method allows to simulate the formation, growth and Ostwald ripening of Cu-rich precipitates [10, 11]. Most studies concentrate on modelling the kinetics in the FeCu-system [12–14]. There are investigations about the behaviour of Mn and Ni [15–18] but they disagree on important model parameters. While the thermodynamically based data of [16, 18] lead to NiMn shells around Cu precipitates, the ab initio based data of [15, 17] favour Ni and Mn dissolved in the
α
$\alpha$ -Fe matrix.

The aim of this work is to gain more insight into the role of Ni and Mn during thermal aging. In Sect. 2.1 we explain the details of the Monte Carlo model. Input data is calculated using ab initio calculations which are described in Sect. 2.2. The influence of temperature on the relevant parameters is taken into account by increasing lattice constants (Sect. 3.1). Our Monte Carlo simulations are performed with varying mixing energies close to the obtained ab initio results. Results are analysed regarding the solubility of Ni and Mn in
α
$\alpha$ -Fe and the composition of evolving precipitates (Sect. 3.2). Finally, summary and conclusions are presented in Sect. 4.

Section2.Heading: Kinetic Monte Carlo method
Section2.Para:
A kinetic Monte Carlo algorithm (KMC) is applied on a rigid bcc lattice with
L = 64
$L=64$ lattice constants. Thus,
N = 2
L 3
$N=2L^{3}$ lattice sites are available which are occupied by Fe, Cu, Ni and Mn atoms and one vacancy. Periodic boundary conditions are used in all directions. Atom movement is simulated via thermally activated vacancy diffusion. In this algorithm, transition rates for an atom of type A are given by 1

$\epsilon^{(i)}_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{B}}$ are calculated from cohesive energies. Other parameters needed for calculation of transition rates are calculated from cohesive energies and vacancy formation and migration energies as described in detail in [10, 11].

Atom jumps are performed using a rejection-free residence time algorithm [12]. Within this method the vacancy is surrounded by eight nearest neighbours and jump rates depending on first and second neighbours are calculated for each of these eight neighbours. Weighted on its probability, one of these eight possibilities is chosen by random. Due to this energy weighting the simulation converges towards an equilibrium state in which atoms occupy sites with preferred local environments (e.g. in precipitates or dissolved in the matrix). Condition for equilibrium state is that types and composition of precipitates as well as solubilities of Cu, Ni and Mn do not change in further calculation.

$D_{0,\mathrm{A}} \approx \nu_{\mathrm{A}} a^{2}$ have no influence on the composition of equilibrium states. With this choice, differences between cohesive energies and vacancy binding energies of Fe, Cu, Ni and Mn are neglected and vacancy trapping effects are suppressed; and simulations up to later stages of precipitation were performed. Vacancy trapping effects and detailed analysis of diffusion kinetics for FeCu have been investigated in an excellent way by Soisson and Fu [13, 19]. Cohesive energies, vacancy formation and migration energies and attempt frequencies contribute to diffusion kinetics. As discussed in [15], some sets of these data slow down convergence and in case of vacancy trapping the equilibrium state cannot be reached. Therefore, for the investigation of the composition of equilibrium states we used cohesive energy (4.28 eV), vacancy formation energy (2.15 eV) and vacancy migration energy (0.66 eV) and attempt frequency (
2.44 ⋅
10
15
$2.44 \cdot 10^{15}$ 1/s) of
α
$\alpha$ -Fe for all elements in the FeCuNiMn-alloy.

Section2.Heading: Ab initio calculations
Section2.Para:
The density functional theory based plane-wave code VASP [20–23] was used to perform spin polarized collinear calculations of mixing energies, vacancy formation energy and vacancy migration energy. All calculations are performed with bcc cubes of 54 sites. The lattice constant was determined by relaxation of an
α
$\alpha$ -Fe cube with volume adjustment of the simulation cell. Following calculations were performed with constant volume.

For migration barrier calculations a
3 × 3 × 3
$3 \times 3 \times 3$ k Monkhorst Pack [24] mesh was used, whereas in mixing energy and vacancy formation energy calculations a
7 × 7 × 7
$7 \times 7 \times 7$ k mesh was adopted. We use projector augmented wave pseudopotentials [25] and the Perdew–Wang 91 generalized gradient approximation [26]. In all calculations the plane-wave cutoff energy was varied in the range from 270 to 600 eV. Relaxation calculations for the following structural compositions were performed:
(1)
54 atoms of type A,
(2)
53 atoms of type Fe, 1 vacancy,
(3)
53 atoms of type A, 1 atom of type B.
From the obtained energies for the relaxed structures the mixing energies
ω

Section2.Heading: Ab initio results
Section2.Para: Relaxation of the bcc Fe cube with 54 lattice sites leads to a lattice constant of 2.83 Å. A vacancy formation energy of 2.15 eV and a vacancy migration energy of 0.66 eV was obtained. As can be seen from Table 2, a plane-wave cutoff energy above 300 eV is sufficient. Obtained values for vacancy formation energy and vacancy migration energy agree very well with the literature data (2.18 and 0.68 eV in [13], respectively 2.02 and 0.65 eV in [15]).

However, the mixing energies which are presented in Table 1 differ from earlier ab initio results. Noticeably the FeCu, FeNi and FeMn values are shifted towards decreased miscibility. The FeCu mixing energy value of −0.7 eV seems to differ significantly from the literature data [13, 15] which lie in the range of −0.46 to −0.55 eV. However, it has to be taken into account that this value was obtained for 0 K in a relaxed Fe lattice with a lattice constant of 2.83 Å. For comparison, we also calculated the mixing energies using a lattice constant of 2.8665 Å which corresponds to
α
$\alpha$ -Fe at room temperature. As can be seen from Table 3 we found a FeCu mixing energy of −0.6 eV which is much closer to the literature data. In addition, the FeMn and FeNi mixing energies are increased from −0.13 to 0.04 eV (FeMn) and from −0.03 to 0.12 eV (FeNi). It should be pointed out that disagreement in the algebraic sign of these mixing energies is found in literature. As can be seen from Table 4, the ab initio calculations of [13] revealed positive values close to zero, which is consistent with increased miscibility; whereas data of [16], which were obtained using a thermodynamical approach with different structures and temperatures, favour segregation.

Tables 1 and 3 show that a plane-wave cutoff energy of 300 eV is sufficient for most mixing energy calculations. Results with different
E cut
$E_{\mathrm{cut}}$ fluctuate in a small range in cases of a Ni or Mn matrix. Since a fixed bcc lattice is used, these results were obtained with structures far away from equilibrium structures of Ni and Mn. In these cases, at some cutoff energies no convergence was achieved. Nevertheless, converged results are quite close to the thermodynamically based data of [16]. A comparison is shown in Table 4. In this overview, mixing energies of material combinations AB–BA (
A , B
∈ {
C u , N i , M n
}
$\mathrm{A,B} \in \{\mathrm{Cu, Ni, Mn}\}$ ) are calculated by averaging mixing energies of AB and BA. A remarkable difference was obtained for CuMn–MnCu. While zero was used in [16], we obtained a quite large negative value of −0.66 eV at
a = 2.83
$a = 2.83$ Å. Unlike for the other combinations, the mixing energies of CuMn and MnCu differ significantly.

In order to estimate the influence of temperature on the mixing energies, calculations with increased lattice constants were performed. Lattice constants of the bcc matrix up to 2.88 Å correspond to temperatures up to 750 K. Results which are shown in Fig. 1 depend significantly on the material combinations. While the mixing energies of CuNi and NiCu are constant in the whole range, all other mixing energies increase with increasing lattice constant. The algebraic signs of FeMn and FeNi mixing energies change from negative to positive, which has strong consequences on the results of Monte Carlo simulations. Most striking is the increase of MnCu and MnNi mixing energies which increase by 1.2 and 0.8 eV, respectively. However, it should be mentioned that magnetic properties of Manganese depend strongly on structure and lattice constant [29]. Furthermore, there are observations of noncollinear magnetism in Manganese [30, 31]. In consideration of this, it has to be stated that especially results of the collinear calculations with Mn matrix might not be suitable to represent configurations of the FeCuNiMn alloy.
Fig. 1
Mixing energies in dependence of lattice constant

Section2.Heading: Kinetic Monte Carlo results
Section2.Para:
Simulations of
10
11
$10^{11}$ KMC steps were performed with concentrations of 2 at.% Cu, Ni, Mn respectively at 573 K. As justified in Sect. 2.2, cohesive energy, vacancy formation and migration energy and diffusion constant of
α
$\alpha$ -Fe were used for all elements in the alloy.

Within the Monte Carlo model the equality
ω
A , B
=
ω
B , A
$\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}=\omega_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}}$ holds true. Since ab initio results presented in Sect. 3.1 do not fulfill this condition, we use the average values of
ω

$\omega_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}} (\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B} \in \{\mathrm{Cu}, \mathrm{Ni}, \mathrm{Mn}\})$ which are listed in Table 4 for KMC simulations. Since this is a rather arbitrary assumption, further Monte Carlo simulations are performed in an extended parameter range. We chose to vary these mixing energies in the range from
ω

$\omega_{\mathrm{Fe,A}}$ (A ∈ {Cu, Ni, Mn}) the two different parameter sets corresponding to different lattice constants (Table 4) were used.

As can be seen from Fig. 2 which shows the equilibrium states for the two parameter sets of
ω
F e , A
$\omega_{\mathrm{Fe,A}}$ with averaged
ω
A , B − B , A
$\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}}$ , the behaviour of Ni and Mn differs significantly. While in the case of larger lattice constant all Ni and Mn atoms stay dissolved in the Fe matrix, NiMn precipitates were observed in the other case. These precipitates show a B2 crystallographic structure and are accumulated to Cu precipitates. There are also Cu precipitates which are incorporated by NiMn precipitates as shown in the upper front corner of the cube visualized in Fig. 2b.
Fig. 2
Obtained equilibrium states with mixing energies of Table 4 resulting from ab initio calculations with different lattice parameter. In case of increased lattice parameter, Ni and Mn atoms stay in solution whereas in the simulation with mixing energies according to the relaxed Fe lattice, formation of NiMn precipitates is observed. Cu: black, Ni: yellow, Mn: blue

Further calculations with the positive values of Table 4 for FeMn and FeNi mixing energies always lead to dissolved Ni and Mn. On the contrary, simulations with
ω FeMn
= − 0.13
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeMn}}=-0.13$ eV and
ω FeNi
= − 0.03
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeNi}}=-0.03$ eV result in various different structures of Ni and Mn dependent on CuMn–MnCu, NiCu–CuNi and NiMn–MnNi mixing energies. Figure 3a–3c shows the results of a systematic parameter study with these negative FeMn and FeNi mixing energies. Each subfigure shows the results of 64 simulations. One out of CuMn–MnCu, NiCu–CuNi and NiMn–MnNi mixing energies is kept fixed at the average value of Table 4 and the other two are varied in ranges from
ω
A , B

It can be seen clearly from Fig. 3 that nine phases were identified. Results visualized in Fig. 4 show these phases which differ in composition of contained precipitates and solubility of Ni and Mn. In all simulations Cu precipitates appear before the formation of NiMn precipitates. The NiMn precipitates with B2 structure were observed in a wide range of mixing energies. As can be seen from Fig. 3a–3c, the main condition is that
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ is at least 0.5 eV. Around this value few NiMn precipitates are observed (Fig. 4c). Lower values result in Cu precipitates and dissolved Ni and Mn atoms (Fig. 4g), in case of positive
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ Ni atoms can be found accumulated to Cu precipitates (Fig. 4a). Increased
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ and
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ can prevent NiMn precipitation since accumulation to Cu is preferred. Figure 3a shows clearly that positive
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ values even lead to embedding of Mn atoms in Cu precipitates. This phase (Fig. 4f) contains only one type of precipitates which consists mostly of Cu with some sites occupied by Mn or Ni. At the interface between precipitate and matrix, enrichment of Mn and Ni is found. In case of large negative values of both
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ and
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ there are clearly separated Cu and NiMn precipitates (Fig. 4h). Increase of these parameters modifies the alignment of Cu and NiMn precipitates so that they are more and more connected (Fig. 4e). Further raise of these parameters leads to NiMn precipitates which enclose at least one Cu precipitate. Most of these Cu precipitates still adjoin the matrix but are mostly embedded in the NiMn precipitate (Fig. 4d). Finally, in case of small negative values of
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ NiMn precipitation is diminished significantly (Fig. 4i) or even completely suppressed (Fig. 4b) in favour of accumulation of Ni and Mn at the interfaces between Cu precipitates and Fe matrix.

The overview of observed phases in dependence of mixing energies (Fig. 3) shows an interesting point regarding KMC results with mixing energies obtained in our ab initio calculations: Results based on ab initio data lie close to borders of other phases. The observed phase contains NiMn precipitates which enclose Cu precipitates. But it can be seen clearly from Fig. 3a and 3b that a small increase of
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ is sufficient to observe a completely different phase without NiMn precipitates, namely the phase containing Cu precipitates with Ni and Mn atoms at the interfaces. In case of a small decrease of
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ the phase with decreased number of NiMn precipitates is observed (Fig. 3a and 3b).

In order to investigate solubility and ratio of Ni and Mn belonging to precipitates, the simulation results were analysed regarding nearest neighbours of these elements. An atom is identified as dissolved in case of eight Fe neighbours. A similar condition is used to detect atoms of NiMn precipitates: a Ni (Mn) atom is part of a NiMn B2 precipitate if at least six neighbours are Mn (Ni) atoms. Finally, Ni or Mn atoms accumulated to Cu precipitates are found by the condition that at least three nearest neighbours are Cu atoms. Figure 5 shows the number of atoms detected using this nearest-neighbour analysis. It can be seen clearly from Fig. 5a–5c that up to 50 % of Ni and Mn is found in NiMn precipitates in case of sufficiently high
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ and sufficiently low
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ . There is a steep increase from the regions without NiMn precipitates to the regions with many Ni and Mn atoms belonging to these clusters. On the contrary, the results regarding accumulation to Cu precipitates (Fig. 5d–5i) are quite continuous. Accumulation of Ni increases with increasing
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ and an analogous behaviour is found for Mn and
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ . Additionally, accumulation is decreased in the regions where NiMn precipitates are observed. In the given parameter range Mn atoms accumulated to Cu precipitates are rare with the exception of the region with positive
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ (Fig. 5g–5i). On the contrary, some Ni atoms accumulate to Cu precipitates at negative
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ also (Fig. 5d–5f). Solubilities of Mn shown in Fig. 5m–5o are high in case of both low
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ and
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ . An increase of
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ leads to small increase of dissolved Mn atoms due to the increased preference of accumulation to Cu precipitates of Ni. Analogous results are found regarding the solubility of Ni (Fig. 5j–5l): Most Ni atoms are in solution in case of low values of
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ and
ω
N i C u − C u N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiCu{-}CuNi}}$ . A small increase is observed at increased

C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ where Mn prefers to occupy sites at Cu precipitates.

Solubility and precipitation of Ni and Mn in dependence of mixing energies (

Section1.Heading: Summary and conclusions
Section1.Para:
Kinetic Monte Carlo simulations of
α
$\alpha$ -Fe based Fe-Cu-Ni-Mn-alloys revealed that both Ni and Mn can be found in various structural compositions. Results are determined by mixing energies. In ab initio calculations it was found that mixing energies increase with increasing lattice constant. As a consequence it can be stated that higher temperatures during thermal annealing which imply larger lattice constants can increase the solubility of Ni and Mn due to this energetic reason. Within the range up to 2.88 Å, which corresponds to a temperature of 750 K, the obtained mixing energies
ω FeMn
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeMn}}$ and
ω FeNi
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeNi}}$ even change their algebraic signs from negative to positive. The effect on the KMC results is drastic: all Ni and Mn atoms stay in solution in case of positive
ω FeMn
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeMn}}$ and
ω FeNi
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeNi}}$ .

In case of fixed negative
ω FeMn
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeMn}}$ and
ω FeNi
$\omega_{\mathrm{FeNi}}$ and in dependence of mixing energies
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ ,
ω
NiMn − MnNi
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn}{-}\mathrm{MnNi}}$ and
ω
NiCu − CuNi
$\omega{_{\mathrm{NiCu}-\mathrm{CuNi}}}$ we presented nine different phases which can be distinguished by alignment and number of NiMn precipitates and the affinity of Ni and Mn to accumulate to Cu precipitates. These investigations were based on ab initio calculations of mixing energies
ω
A , B
$\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}$ and
ω
B , A
( A , B ∈ { Cu , Ni , Mn } )
$\omega_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}} (\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B} \in \{\mathrm{Cu}, \mathrm{Ni}, \mathrm{Mn}\})$ and KMC simulations were performed in the range from
ω
A , B
$\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}$ to
ω
B , A
$\omega_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}}$ . It was found that NiMn precipitates reported in experiments [7] can form in case of
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ higher than 0.5 eV and negative
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ . Cu precipitates surrounded by Mn and Ni atoms which were also observed in experiments [1] were found in our KMC simulations in a quite narrow range of mixing energies. Condition is that
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ is lower than 0.6 eV and
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ is between −0.7 and 0 eV.

Most interesting is the result of the KMC simulation with ab initio based data using the approximation
ω
A , B − B , A
= (
ω
A , B
+
ω
B , A
) / 2
$\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}} = (\omega_{\mathrm{A},\mathrm{B}}+\omega_{\mathrm{B},\mathrm{A}})/2$ . In this simulation NiMn precipitates were observed. However, the mixing energies are very close to values which lead to different structural compositions of Ni and Mn. A small decrease of
ω
N i M n − M n N i
$\omega_{\mathrm{NiMn{-}MnNi}}$ leads to a significant decrease in the number of NiMn precipitates whereas a small increase of
ω
C u M n − M n C u
$\omega_{\mathrm{CuMn{-}MnCu}}$ diminishes the formation of NiMn precipitates completely. In the latter case the phase with Cu precipitates surrounded by Mn and Ni atoms is obtained as reported in [16, 18].

In contrast to our simplified model with ideal bcc lattice, real
α
$\alpha$ -Fe based Fe-Cu-Ni-Mn-alloys possess internal stresses and contain various types of defects such as grain boundaries, dislocations, precipitates and foreign atoms. These defects and hereby induced internal stresses have strong influence regarding energetically favourable environments for atoms of any specific element. Taken into account that small changes of the mixing energies of our simulations lead to completely different structural compositions, it can be understood that a large variety of Cu-rich and NiMn-rich precipitates are observed in experiments.
